name: Insignia Consultancy Solutions
description: Insignia specializes in technology solutions for digital transformation. As a software development intern on the data science team, I work closely with large language models and Python programming. My role involves creating integrated solutions using tools like Hugging Face, OpenAI, Groq API, and Assembly AI. Despite having no prior AI background, I've successfully contributed to three major projects in just two months, including a Sentence Analyzer and real-time speech-to-text pipeline.

designs.title: Realtime Speech to Text Pipeline
designs.description: After delivering the previous project of STT pipeline, I worked on a realtime audio transcription system using Flask and various large language models (LLMs). The transcription process begins by capturing audio input, which is then processed to detect silence and manage recording efficiently. The system integrates multiple transcription services, applying robust error handling and retry mechanisms for API calls to ensure reliability. Additionally, it supports offline transcription using the Vosk framework. This project showcases my ability to integrate diverse technologies, implement complex workflows, and maintain a clean architecture while ensuring secure operations through logging and environment management.

designs.title: Speech to Text Pipeline
designs.description: Here, I developed a speech-to-text pipeline using Flask that enables users to record their voice and convert it to text with various large language models (LLMs). The project includes over nine core files, with pipeline.py as the main entry point. It features main.py for routing, start.py and stop.py for recording control, and config.py for managing model configurations and API keys. The transcription is handled in process.py, while a .env file stores critical parameters securely. I implemented centralized logging in logger.py to ensure comprehensive session tracking. This project showcases my expertise in building complex systems from scratch, utilizing technologies like Flask and external libraries for audio processing, along with a clear architectural design illustrated in a high-level flowchart.

designs.title: Sentence Analyzer
designs.description: In this project, I utilized Python to extract key travel-related information from sentences, leveraging powerful libraries like SpaCy for natural language processing and FuzzyWuzzy for string matching. The code was designed to identify source and destination locations, dates, and times from diverse texts, using regex patterns to capture various date and time formats, including relative references like 'tomorrow.' Additionally, I expanded the sentence analyzer to extract event names, guest counts, durations, and more, making the tool robust and versatile for applications in travel, event planning, and beyond. With over 1,500 lines of code, I'm proud of how this tool streamlines the process of gathering and organizing critical information, enhancing efficiency for users in both domains.

name: New Jersey Institute of Technology
description: At New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT), a top research university in Newark, I worked part-time as a Teaching Assistant while pursuing my MS in Computer Science. I first assisted with CS 656: Internet and Higher Layer Protocols, then returned the following semester for CS 630: Operating Systems Design. In both roles, I supported students with coursework, labs, and projects, deepening my technical knowledge while contributing to NJITâ€™s research-driven academic environment.

designs.title: TA for CS630: Operating Systems Design
designs.description: For CS 630 I had a class of more than 100 to handle with help of one more TA. Here I assisted the professor in assessing class participation, which was something newly introduced by me and my partner TA. In the assessing process we would keep track of each student who is answering professor's question, or actively asking doubts and being proactive in interacting with on going topics of studies. I also assisted in assessing midterm and final exams while also supervising them to ensure there was no misconduct or cheating taking place. To avoid the cheating we

designs.title: TA for CS656: Internet and Higher Layer Protocols
designs.description: As a Teaching Assistant for CS 656: Internet and Higher Layer Protocols at NJIT, I played a key role in both designing and delivering course materials. Before being officially hired, I worked with the professor to develop a set of evaluation methods, including three mini-projects and one major project. These projects were designed to help students gain practical experience with various layers of network protocols, utilizing tools such as NS2, Cisco Packet Tracer, and client-server programming in Python. For the final major project, students were tasked with transforming their third mini-project into a globally hosted chat server using ngrok or other third-party platforms. In addition to designing projects, my responsibilities included explaining project concepts, assisting students with lab work, and providing guidance on course material. I also supported grading for over 40 students, evaluating lab assignments, projects, and exams, ensuring timely and constructive feedback to help students improve their understanding of networking concepts. This experience allowed me to strengthen my communication and technical skills while contributing to a collaborative learning environment.
